title: Acid-Base Neutralization
description: Master titration and learn about chemical neutralization through precise experimentation
objectives: Understand and perform acid-base titration accurately
Recognize the equivalence point using indicators
Learn about the pH scale and neutralization reactions

keyTerms.definition: A laboratory technique to determine the concentration of a solution by reacting it with a solution of known concentration
The point at which the amount of acid exactly equals the amount of base - moles of H+ = moles of OH-
A logarithmic scale from 0-14 measuring acidity (0-6), neutrality (7), or basicity (8-14)
A chemical reaction between an acid and a base producing a salt and water
A substance that changes color based on pH, used to visually detect the equivalence point
A graduated glass tube with a tap for accurately delivering small volumes of liquid
The solution of known concentration that is added from the burette
The solution of unknown or variable concentration being analyzed

safetyConsiderations: Always wear safety goggles - acid and base splashes cause eye damage
Wear a laboratory coat and nitrile gloves
If acid or base contacts skin, wash immediately with running water for at least 15 minutes
Work with dilute solutions (1M or less)
Never add water to acid - always add acid to water
Keep spill kits nearby and know how to use them
Handle burettes carefully - they are fragile glass equipment
Dispose of acids and bases according to laboratory waste procedures

supplies.description: pH indicator solution (colorless in acid, pink in base)

procedure.setup: Set up the burette on a stand with burette clamp. Rinse all glassware with distilled water.

steps: Rinse the burette with small portions of the NaOH solution 3-4 times
Fill the burette with NaOH solution, ensuring no air bubbles are present
Record the initial burette reading (usually 0.00 mL)
Pipette exactly 25mL of HCl into a conical flask
Add 2-3 drops of phenolphthalein indicator to the flask
Place a white tile under the flask to better see color changes
Position the flask under the burette tip
Slowly open the stopcock to add NaOH drop by drop
As you approach the equivalence point, the color persists longer
Add NaOH dropwise when the solution starts showing pink color
Stop when the solution changes from colorless to faint pink
Calculate the volume of NaOH used: Final reading - Initial reading
Repeat the titration 2-3 times with fresh HCl
Discard the solution after each titration
Calculate average volume of NaOH used

calculations.formula: Moles of acid = Moles of base at equivalence point

example.description: If 25mL of 1.0M HCl requires 25mL of 1.0M NaOH

observations.initial: HCl is colorless; after adding indicator, stays colorless (acidic)
observations.during: As NaOH is added, the solution gradually changes from colorless to light pink
observations.atEquivalence: Solution is at pH 7 (neutral); color is light yellow/colorless
observations.afterEquivalence: Excess NaOH makes solution pink/light red (basic)

chemicalEquation.ionic: H⁺(aq) + Cl⁻(aq) + Na⁺(aq) + OH⁻(aq) → Na⁺(aq) + Cl⁻(aq) + H₂O(l)

conclusion.mainFinding: Neutralization occurs when equal moles of acid and base react, producing salt and water. The equivalence point can be detected precisely using pH indicators.
evidence: All three titrations showed consistent volume of base needed (approximately 25mL)
Indicator color changed from colorless to pink at equivalence point
Both solutions disappeared and formed a neutral salt solution
conclusion.implications: Understanding titration allows chemists to determine unknown concentrations and verify chemical reactions

quizQuestions.question: In a neutralization reaction, what reacts with the acid?

options.text: A base to form salt and water
Water to form a more dilute solution
Another acid to form a stronger acid

quizQuestions.explanation: Acid + Base → Salt + Water. This is the fundamental neutralization reaction. The acid (H⁺) reacts with the base (OH⁻) to produce water and a salt.

quizQuestions.question: Why is a pH indicator essential in titration?

options.text: To speed up the chemical reaction
To visually indicate when the equivalence point is reached
To control the temperature of the solution

quizQuestions.explanation: Indicators change color at the equivalence point, allowing precise detection of when the acid and base have completely neutralized each other. This is critical for accurate titration results.

quizQuestions.question: What is the color of phenolphthalein in acidic solution?
quizQuestions.explanation: Phenolphthalein is colorless in acidic solutions (pH < 8.2) and turns pink/red in basic solutions (pH > 8.2). This color change helps identify the equivalence point in titration.

quizQuestions.question: What is the pH value at the equivalence point of a strong acid-strong base titration?
quizQuestions.explanation: At the equivalence point of a strong acid-strong base reaction, the solution is neutral with pH = 7 because moles of H⁺ exactly equal moles of OH⁻.

quizQuestions.question: In the titration, what is the purpose of recording burette readings?

options.text: To calculate the volume of titrant used

quizQuestions.explanation: The volume of NaOH used is calculated as Final Reading - Initial Reading. This volume is essential for determining the concentration of the unknown acid using stoichiometry.
